job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Pasadena, CA
pros: Small school so it's easy to know a lot of people. Area is expensive to live in, but the school offers one-year of on-campus subsidized housing to help grad students settle into Pasadena life.
cons: Small school so not a lot of research groups to choose from unless you're in chemistry (which I am!) Pricey neighborhood. I wish Caltech offered more time to live on campus other than through the housing lottery system. A lot of bureaucracy happens through emails or phone calls. Want to set up an appointment with the counseling center? Phone call. Want a checkup at the school heath center? Phone call. Even instrumentation scheduling is based on how the research group who owns the instrument works. Sometimes it's an email, sometimes it's a google calendar.

job_title: University Postdoctoral Fellow in Pasadena, CA
pros:
Lots of bright people to work with
Plenty of project funding opportunities
Good weather and outdoorsy stuff in Pasadena
Endless interesting projects to work on
Easy access to LA on public transit
cons:
-Poor department culture: there is a lack of feeling like you belong in the department because the department is so big and people don't socialize between research groups
-People themselves are really nice but overall there is a lack of humbleness in whole. Professors have a mentality of "oh you're overworked? welcome to postdoc life". A lot of 'this is how academia is' and dumping work on grad students too
-People work a lot and take on too many projects (and too many funding deadlines that are short on labor) and will sign you up to do things without asking. They rely on postdocs to do a lot of department/project tasks that shouldn't be our jobs. If you're an independent fellow, beware, you are free labor
-Pasadena is super spread out, makes meeting up to socialize harder
Salary of a postdoc isnt great when you consider how much we could be making in industry at the hours we work. You wont be able to afford a home in Pasadena on your salary alone, and studio or one bedroom rent prices are stressful enough
-the weather rarely changes. it's weird after a while

review_title: Good research, great colleagues, avoid HR
pros:
From an academic-track postdoc fellow:
* Great research environment, world class colleagues and facilities.
cons:
* Most admins within my division are mildly effective at best and obstructive at worst.
* Opaque salary scale and promotion structure.
* Minimal flexibility in health care plans.
* Retirement benefits for three-year post docs kick in at… the beginning of year 3!
* Within the academic career path, you do not make very much money given your skill set.
* Within the academic career path, depending on field, the ratio of PhDs to faculty positions is typically 10:1. This means the jobs are rarely permanent.

Institute does not protect the rights of its postdocs, it just lets PIs exploit them

review_title: You'll probably not go out the way you went in!
pros: Vacation, and matching retirement fund contributions.  Awesome visiting speakers & guest lecturers.  Good athletic facility for use by faculty, students & staff.  I should have made more use of the lovely Atheneum faculty & staff club when I was there.  The academic environment must be getting better if the poor stressed-to-the-max students have stopped snuffing themselves out.
cons: Some departments are in need of facility & infrastructure maintenance and renovation.  I experienced near constant environmental issues, i.e., noise, heat, and noxious smells, usually from points of origin outside my lab or office.  My working space was heavily infested by vertebrate & invertebrate pests for some months in 2011-12.  It took some time for facilities management to finally mount an effective response.  If your supervisor is not effective at conflict resolution, there's not really any available venue of recourse.  The Ombud's office was eliminated some years back.  The culture in some research support entities can be very oppressive for staff.  To get the best results from staff, concentrate on inspirado, and incentive, not disparagement & retribution.

review_title: Best place on Earth if you can handle the workload and the nerdy environment
pros:
People here are so damn smart. If you enjoy intelligent (although it may be quite nerdy) discussions, this place is for you.
People here are also very friendly if you find the right people using the house system implemented here. Instead of normal dorms, Caltech students are divided into houses. People fortunately have a tendency to end up where they belong. You may not always feel like you fit in there at first but there is a good chance you will end up at a house that you belong it even if you don't know it. This lets everybody to find this school feel comfortable (socially of course. academically? now that's a completely different story)
cons: The workload is pretty intense. Also people here are so smart that you won't be able to help but feel dumb at times. However, this I find is a problem you will never get away from if you want to end up in a challenging but rewarding environments (and if you're not looking for such an environment, you should not come here. trust me you will not be able to find a single review that says that this place is relaxing and easy-going)

review_title: A well funded university with lots of perks and community benefits that you won't find at larger university.
pros: The small size of the university makes it a pretty cozy work environment.  Because the university has typically has large scale resources, there are lots of perks that go with being an employee here.  Plenty of office and department parties, seminars, events that come with free meals.  The campus is beautiful and easy to get things done because there are not a lot of barriers to access the most Senior management people.  There are many events open to entire community.  Cultural programming at Beckman auditorium, educational lectures by some of the world's greatest scientists, and musical programs give the campus a decent cultural life despite its small size and isolation from other universities.  Case in point: the Caltech Olive Festival.  Nowhere else would this have happened.
cons: Being a small university is both a curse and a blessing.  Many people within the administration were used to doing things in a unstructured, less-professional way because it is a small university and there are a smaller number of people to serve.  Large turnover, "changing of the guard", and restructuring has occurred at Caltech in the administration over the last 5 years and the downsides are getting better, but remnants of the past are still there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA

review_title: Caltech can be ideal if you have a good advisor.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pasadena, CA
pros: The people at Caltech are amazing.  The other graduate students are not stereotypical nerds, but simply very smart and interested in the world around them. The campus is beautiful and the weather is great, if you like constant sunshine. :) Caltech has a very small student population, and so pretty much every face on campus is familiar, which can be a good or bad thing.  The research opportunities are top noch and unbeatable. Did I mention that everyone is really, really nice? I have never encountered such a concentration of intelligent and kind people anywhere else.  But what Caltech is know for most of all is its reserach.
cons: All of the budget cuts are annoying and bad for morale.  Advisors seem to be very self-absorbed and very few are good mentors.  Caltech is so small that if you're not interested in working on one of the very few topics that are the specialties of the professors there, you're sort of screwed. (This is particularly troublesome if you *think* you know what you want to work on, and then change your mind after the first year.  The possibilities for a new advisor are very limited.) They also keep reducing the health insurance benefits for grad students.

pros:
Good benefits
Good people
There are Nice people who work there
cons:
Too much gossip all the time
Favoritism

review_title: Good and bad at the same time, and depends on PI
pros: Surrounded by smart and driven people who I could learn from constantly and be motivated by, pretty good benefits, beautiful campus that I loved going to every day, small community, ability to do and be a part of impactful discoveries, my lab was understanding with the need for flexibility for appointments and such, and my direct supervisor took employee rights pretty seriously, the lab had an informal and really fun/hilarious vibe. Many of the people were very caring and great team players and made the pros of my time there really special.
cons: If you're not in a good lab, the people can be very condescending and even cruel, even in a good lab, the people (like your direct supervisor) can occasionally be degrading, as a lab tech (depending on the lab) you may be treated as just a set of hands and literally blocked from growing beyond that, some labs overwork their techs, expecting them to work the hours of a grad student without the benefits that come from being a grad student (working towards an eventual degree, for example) or over-time benefits (even if they are eligible).

review_title: An excellent place to do scientific research among the best and brightest in the world.
pros: All of my coworkers are top-notch. Team-based projects move quickly and there's never "that one person" who doesn't contribute. The research opportunities are excellent too. For being such a small school, there's plenty of funding and a wide variety of cutting edge applied and fundamental research projects ongoing.
cons: Work-life balance can be extremely difficult at times. Extended hours are expected, as is a "whatever it takes" attitude. Paternity leave is nominally two weeks without pay, though there are ongoing efforts to change that. Time off is generous for people young in their careers if you can take it - two weeks plus institute holidays, which accounts for approximately 20 days (vacation + holidays) per year. The challenge is finding time that works with the funding cycle and research schedule to take that time off.

pros: Attracts brilliant people, hosts cutting-edge research, very small university that takes care of students individually and flexibly, flexible hours, great career prospects
cons: It is easy to get sucked into an unhealthy work-life balance, as a lot of people work very hard. One has to make a conscious effort to withstand the pressure, but it is possible. Grad student salary is very low, but that's an issue with science in general and not with Caltech (Caltech's salary may be pretty good compared to other universities, but I don't know for sure).

review_title: Great Place to work, w/ caveats
job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in Pasadena, CA
pros:
- Almost unlimited resources for your research
- Very smart colleagues
- Productive Environment
- Great fun to do great work
- Great cafeterias
- Decent gym and swimming pool
cons:
- Post-docs have to pay for the gym (used to be for free, and is for free for students and other faculty)
- Post-docs are low priority, relatively, for HR. I found that they were not very motivated to help with issues regarding housing and other benefits, insisting on arbitrary rules, even under exceptional circumstances.
- The administration is a bit slow in responding to complains about (sexually, verbally, socially) abusive famous faculty.  I think there is room for improvement, and it is underway.
- Caltech puts a relatively low cap on salaries for post-docs, so that the salaries are lower than they are at many other, similar institutions, despite the high cost of living in Pasadena.

review_title: Great Place - If You're in the Right Department
pros:
- Great retirement contributions 
- Wonderful co-workers
- Good work-life balance if you're in the right department 
- Beautiful Campus
cons:
- It takes months to get anything approved
- Annual Salary Increase barely meets inflation - let alone higher health contributions and more expensive parking year after year - Plan on making less net pay based on increased annual deductions
- Low pay for many jobs because they use the national average rather than  California average to determine salary
- People work here forever, so they are uncomfortable with any type of change
- Old, outdated processes of doing things
- In my department severe lack of communication 
- Managers in my department hired their friends, not the most qualified candidates 
- My department required many people do tasks  outside of their job. If it was addressed with your manager, the response was, "other duties as assigned." 
- Rarely any growth unless you switch departments

review_title: Good benefits, mediocre pay, laid-back environment
pros:
Overall, benefits and vacation time are good, and the environment is pretty laid-back for employees (less so for students). The campus is a pretty place to walk around, and you have access to on-campus activities and lectures. The campus is walking distance to nearby restaurants and shops.

Management depends on who you work for. Each department is fairly autonomous, so some are better than others.

Since it's a small university, bureaucracy is not as bad as at larger places, although it's still there.
cons:
In general, pay is lower than in industry, but how much lower depends on what you do and where you work. My pay is significantly lower. Career growth is also limited.

Parking costs money and will become more scarce because of parking lots closing to be replaced by new buildings.

Gym membership used to be free for staff, but now costs money. It's still cheaper than commercial gyms.

Although working at Caltech is usually stable, there have been layoffs.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pasadena, CA
pros: Caltech is widely regarded as a superior educational institution by the outside world.  When you go to conferences, meetings or job interviews your affiliation with Caltech commands respect.
cons: Caltech is overloaded with administration and bureaucracy.  For an institution this small and this focused on one thing - science and engineering - there is a remarkable amount of overhead associated with the Administration.  My research laboratory provides a enormous amount of money to the Institute for services and administration, but any time there is a facilities problem or a management issue it takes days or weeks to resolve.  As a graduate student, I feel constantly hamstrung by this overhead and unable to focus on science.

review_title: Excellent benefits offset by terrible politics
pros:
Benefits are wonderful - days off (with pay) between Christmas and New Year's, 3 weeks of vacation upon start, employer pays a large percentage of insurance premiums
Beautiful campus in a park-like setting
Highly intelligent people
Excellent reputation
Stability - Caltech is not going anywhere!
cons:
Politics are reminiscent of high school
Entrenched mediocrity is rewarded
Excessive emphasis on collaboration stalls many projects and initiatives; there's a meeting for everything
Results are not ultimately not rewarded and are undervalued to preserve and maintain relationships
Employees with longetivy are valued even when they are no longer contributing; newcomers are often perceived as a threat to the status quo
The values communicated to staff are not adhered to by management

pros: Great Campus, friendlyworkers, great benefits, wonderful cafeteria great faculty, and so many different things to be able to take part in on your own time.  Overall  a nice place to work
cons: Management of Facilities has changed, not for the better.  You used to see a conceern for the employee.  Management is not there to help the employee.Other departments are better to work for.  Not enough opportunities for advancement

pros: Employees are treated fairly and with respect. Benefits are excellent and wages are average or above average. Safety is an actual priority, not just a CYA exercise like many places. People seem to actually care for one another.
cons: Lack of management, chain of command not always clear. Left hand often unaware of the right hand, so to speak. Technical decisions not always sound due to large ego's. Managers often do not have real-world experience or experience managing people. Advancement is difficult and positions are filled by who has the most education versus ability. Technical meetings are often a "who's the smartest" contest, resulting in poor decision making.

pros: Caltech has great benefits, start off vacation was higher than most places. The location is lovely. There was a good sense of comradery among the researchers in my lab.  Not to mention you are working at one of the world's leading academic research institutes.  It is not uncommon to hear that people of interest are moving around campus, giving talks.  Everyone from Stephen Hawking to Bill Nye.
cons:
The expectations of employees in research positions could be closer to that of grad students or post docs depending on the lab.  Playing the game according to HR's rules is very different from playing the game using your immediate boss' rules.  I have heard, though indirectly, that HR/higher-ups would rather let you go than discipline a professor.

However this may be a problem in all of academia.

pros: Caltech is full of really smart motivated people. The campus is beautiful. It is small enough that you won't be anonymous and you can easily end up collaborating across departments and interacting with people outside of your field.
cons: If you are a young single graduate student, you might find the gender ratio and small size socially frustrating. If you decide things aren't working out with the professor you came to work with, the institute is small enough that there might not be someone else working in your area of interest

pros: Caltech emphasizes retention in addition to recruitment. Benefits are great, especially the less common ones - free access to excellent gym on campus, flexibility in working hours if you're an exempt employee, casual dress code.  The focus here is on excellence - you are working with the best of the best and you know it. HR strives to provide continuing education plus their support for new managers is superior.
cons: The culture and history of each division of Caltech is very independent which affects the budgeting process. Every division can do it's own thing. Sometimes this leads to duplicated spending, especially when it comes to infrastructure type things like IT support, and library. Management could focus a bit more on achieving economies of scale by eliminating redundancies.

pros: Great school, according to those who try to measure such things.  I don't disagree.  There are probably better places to compare grad schools than Glassdoor.  Experiences across departments and labs vary so much that it's really impossible to review Caltech as a whole.  Talk to people in your prospective program and try to see if they are miserable.  One generalization that I will make (and with which others will certainly disagree) is that surprisingly, the atmosphere is truly more collaborative than it is competitive.  If you like outdoor activities (climbing, skiing, mountain biking, hiking, ocean stuff) Pasadena is a pretty good base camp (okay, maybe not for the ocean stuff, but you can make it work).
cons: If you pick a bad advisor, you will have a bad time.

job_title: Research Support Assistant in Pasadena, CA
pros: Working at Caltech has given opportunities available nowhere else.  In a lab position you are encouraged to learn new disciplines and participate in research above and beyond your job description.  As a research assistant I was given the opportunity to pursue independent research and co-author several papers.  Health care benefits are also generous and the campus facilities and resources (gym, recreational clubs, etc) are available to staff.
cons: An intense work environment can lead to a feeling that maintaining a good work/life balance is impossible.  The situation has improved in the last several years, and there is now more strict enforcement of salaried employees' hours (preventing them from overworking).  Salary is not high, and for several years the institute froze raises (including cost of living adjustments).

job_title: Graduate Student In Aeronautics in Pasadena, CA
pros: I completed my PhD and this is pretty much the top Aerospace program in the world, so it's hard to complain about that. It has done well for me career wise. The pay was adequate (no one gets rich off grad school, but I was paid enough to meet my expenses and live reasonably.)
cons: It's a small place, so if there are personal or other conflicts, it's hard to disappear or blend in. Most classes are not offered frequently enough due to the small size of the department and the large number of professors who have time release for one reason or another.

review_title: Science lover's paradise, nerdy or not.
pros: Caltech is undeniably one of the top leading research university in the world. Researchers have very open mind to the neighboring research area and therefore there are plenty of opportunities to collaborate with other researchers in the related fields. Sitting at the edge of the Los Angeles metropolitan area, one can enjoy diverse cultural life as well as various outdoor life such as beach-going and skiing. If you are single and love sciences, this is the place to be.
cons: Since it is mostly a educational institution, Caltech does not have a strong compensation system for its postdoctoral researchers. I guess this is true with other universities. Pasadena is a very expensive place to live in too. However,it should be OK if you are single.

pros: Beautiful campus and surroundings; great holiday schedule and PTO benefits; a chance to work alongside some really intelligent individuals; decent employer contribution to your 401k; Caltech is recognized worldwide for its excellence in education and research; very good work-life balance.
cons: Typically low pay; the campus is pretty small, so transferring can be difficult and very competitive; not all divisions operate the same, so some employees enjoy schedule flexibility and holiday perks more than others - it's a matter of getting lucky and landing in a division/department that fits with your preferences/needs.

review_title: An Intellectual Oasis in L.A. County
pros:
During my time there, I operated without any interaction with the school's management.  As a research assistant, my life was entirely within the division where I was working.

The campus is absolutely beautiful, the type of environment that rewards walking to collect one's thoughts.  It's also a great collection of minds and eclectic tastes.  (Speaking of tastes, I was also impressed by the dining hall on campus.)
cons: I have heard some talk about recent funding difficulties in various departments, but this is a phenomenon hardly restricted to Caltech, and it did not affect me.  Any other possible cons are based on hearsay and not my personal experience, so I won't list them here.

review_title: A challenging but rewarding place to work at
pros: Caltech is a top level research institute which equipped with great research facilities. People here are nice and very competent at their work. You can learn a lot by working at Caltech. Plus, Pasadena is a great city to live in.
cons: Working at Caltech as a research people could be very challenging. You need to be self-motivated and able to plan things very well. Also, you need to be able to balance your work with your personal life, which is sometimes as challenging as work itself

pros: The cultural focus is academic research and is geared to promote collaboration and sharing of resources.  This is a significant attribute in allowing creative, inventive ideas to be  tried out, whether it is using facilities or talking with other departments.
cons: It's very research centered, and there are no humanities to balance out people. There is not much social cohesion or interaction, everyone is in their silo.  It's also a very high pressure environment so most people are stressed, but that's about the norm in high caliber academics.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Pasadena, CA
pros: GPS is one of the best divisions on campus when it comes to student happiness. Everyone is brilliant and hardworking, and it's easy to network with many of the top names in the field. Seminars are abundant, and there are lots of fun departmental events throughout the year. Pick your graduate advisor carefully, as there are many different working styles and this will have the biggest effect on your happiness and success in grad school. Employers love recruiting at Caltech.
cons: The work load is heavy, and the environment can often be stressful and guilt inducing. Hanging on to hobbies and spending time with friends can be a challenge but are necessary for long term happiness.

review_title: A COOL PLACE TO WORK OR RELAX.
pros: The campus has a very natural and peaceful environment. I liken it to a park with lots of trees, turtles, egrets, squirrels, and birds. It is open to the public, many of the neighbors come through jogging or walking their dog. The grounds are immaculate with a variety of flowers to create a beautiful positive place for creative mind.
cons: Office politics can sometimes get in the way of progress which may actually be typical for most organizations. I guess in comparison to other places the hierarchy is pretty level compared to others places. Hence this may in some sense be an positive attribute rather than a con.

review_title: Caltech as a narrowly focused research institution
pros: Excellent resources, good tenure rate, freedom for junior profs to pursue research of their choice. A great city/region in which to live. A great place to be a WASP male.
cons: Note the best place if you are interested in teaching, outreach or inclusion. This is a very narrowly focused institute that does one thing well (research) at the expense of others. Lots of elitism. Not all departments/divisions have good leadership.

review_title: Great place to work, if you're faculty.
pros: Decent benefits and other perks like tuition reimbursement, gym on campus. (Even though you have to pay. Still cheaper than a regular him ) Good time off benefits.
cons: If you are faculty it's great. You can literally do whatever you. If you are staff there's no training, no support, and you are thrown under the bus on a daily. While you have good time of benefits don't try to use them or be sick. Upper management hates when you do that.

review_title: A rare, nurturing environment; a haven for cutting-edge research; a meritocracy with minimal politics involved.
pros: Co-workers, peers, and superiors are all extremely intelligent.  There is great camaraderie and an atmosphere of cooperation and information sharing.  Compared to most other research institutions, there is minimal politics at Caltech.
cons: In just about all the research areas it covers Caltech is a national/international leader, but due to its small size there are some research areas which Caltech has no faculty specializing in.  So compared to its East-Coast counterpart, MIT, Caltech has greater depth but less breadth depending on the field.

review_title: You should go here and work here.
pros: Working or studying here is a great opportunity, if you can get admitted or hired.  This is a very driven and high producing campus, across all disciplines, so you can expect the culture to push you to your best.  The undergraduate community is unique, in the absolute best ways (but sometimes, also the worst ways).  Being a teaching assistant lets you get to know some very prestigious faculty besides your adviser.
cons: The school is small, so might not have as rich of opportunities to collaborate with others within your department (some groups are very specialized and non-overlapping).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pasadena, CA
pros: Caltech is a very small school which makes it very easy to switch fields of research and to communicate with people out of your own department.  There are smart people around everywhere.
cons: Choosing a bad advisor might result in no life /work balance.  Also, the place does not feel like a college campus.  It is a good place to do research, but not for taking classes.

review_title: Not my best life decision yet
pros: Most of the staff — department admins, the diversity center, HR, etc — and the occasional professor genuinely care about the students. The campus is beautiful and there are lots of brilliant, quirky people.
cons:
The culture is not very inclusive and is very competitive. Sexism and homophobia are too common. 

Arrogance is rampant and can create toxic environments.

Don’t expect to learn from most classes. There are a few passionate educators but almost no one is *really* paid to teach.

Some professors are well known for exploitative practices so always speak to other students before signing on with an advisor.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pasadena, CA
pros: The opportunities at Caltech are incredible.  It's a steaming mass of smart people with creativity oozing out of every crevice.  If you're prepared to take advantage of it it's a great place to launch an academic career.
cons: It's hard to find a professor there who's also a good mentor.  Most of them are more focused on research, which makes sense given the place's reputation.  If you need guidance there might be better options.

pros: The research and people are among the very best in the world.  I worked in several tier 1 research institutions, and Caltech definitely deserves its reputation.
cons: The department in which I worked tended to be a bit too secretive in its administrative and hiring processes.  Other institutions involve students and research staff more in decisions that affect the entire department, which leads to a better feeling of community.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pasadena, CA
pros: Flexible hours, interesting work. Most days are low stress. In one way or another, working as a GRA exercises your scientific skills.  Often, we are given opportunities to teach, also.
cons: Often hours are long, and the experience is highly dependent on your PI/Advisor.  And the fact is, for better or for worse, this is effectively an apprenticeship--we are ostensibly in a "teaching by doing" program, that is effectively cheap research labor.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pasadena, CA
pros: There are a lot of high quality resources and people at Caltech. While this is not the rule in every department - a clever student will have an easy time taking advantage of the many opportunities here.
cons: Students should be prepared to take full responsibility for their progress, those who do not sometimes slip through the cracks. Also professional and effective support staff are not uniformly distributed over campus.

review_title: I'll think back fondly on this place...if I ever get to leave.
job_title: Graduate Student In Chemistry in Pasadena, CA
pros: beautiful location, nearby hiking, easy to access entertainment in LA but can avoid the rush-hour traffic, top-notch coworkers, lots of instruments/ money for research, health center
cons: little guidance, easy to get stuck in your current position, can be a very negative work environment, low pay in an expensive city

review_title: Was a great company to work for, but they laid me off after 12 years of good service. They have become very corporate.
pros: Good benefits (which start the month you begin), IRA (retirement, not 401k), access to Caltech facilities like gym, recording studio, credit union, etc. Decent vacation time (starts at almost 3 weeks per year, after 5 years goes up, after 10 years goes to nearly one month per year. Some departments still use the honor code, and don't look over your shoulder as you work. Many other departments were reformatted with corporate influence. They brought people in from the corporate world to see how they could save money during the 08/09 deprecession (yes, I wrote deprecession, because it lasted too long to be a recession, but not long enough to be a depression).
cons: The pay is abysmal. This is the trade off for being at the top of your field. Caltech is the best school in the world to study science, and working there is a great opportunity and resume builder. They just pay next to nothing, because they know that the people working there are there for the job, not the money. After they brought in the corporate consultants (people from the corporate world to tell them how to save money), they threw the honor code out the window for staff (it still applies to professors and students). Prior to this, you could take a two hour lunch and go to the gym (for free), park for free, and make up time when you didn't work your full 8 hours. That all went away, as now you have to clock in and out using Kronos, they are sticklers for the rules (you have to take your lunch before the five hour mark or you get written up). The lab I worked in had an incredible vibe when I first started working there, where everyone enjoyed their job, was excited to be a part of Caltech, and couldn't say a bad thing about working there. Once they had the corporate consultants come in (after the deprecession), the whole ,morale of the department tanked once this happened.

job_title: Research Engineer in Big Pine, CA

cons: As with all research, funding can be a problem. You never know if the project you work for will be funded for the next cycle. If not, you might be out of a job. Compensation has been below industry average, but the benefits and work / life balance make up for it (for me).

review_title: Management Needs to work towards goals and understand limitations

cons: There is a fair amount of it must be invented here mentality, which makes sense for research but is enormously ineffective for administration of a relatively small institution. There is a lot of stress and pressure on the employees, and entrenched employees with serious HR issues.

pros: Your satisfaction depends on you PI of course. But Caltech is a great place to work for postdocs. Its small enough that you can go to job fairs and other social events with students. Benefits are good for postdocs too, because they lump us with the staff. PI's are very smart, and the environment is very collaborative.
cons: It is small, and doing research is hard because of lack of collaborators. For eg, there was only 1 FACS sorter which was used for bacterial cells, fungi, fish etc.

pros: Hard to think of any right now

This means you will have to pay estimated taxes throughout the year, which is a huge pain.  This makes me very glad that I'm no longer there, but until April 15th 2016, the nightmare of doing my taxes will remind me how awful it was to be a postdoc there.

If you are not getting along well with your advisor, it may be very hard to find another professor who is working on related areas.

review_title: This is a place to spend your lifetime. You can move up, sideways and up again if you really want it.

Too many little fiefdoms, not enough opportunity for advancement or education. Within organizations, people tend to focus on deflecting work / blame, rather than working together to get things done. Faculty can be very spoiled and "run the show".
